metadata.case_name: Appellant (adopted son of Krishnarao via Rukminibai) v. Respondents (sons of Devji)

facts.text: Siddopant and Krishnarao were members of a joint undivided family, sons of Ramchandra, entitled to half share of Watan lands: whole of S. No. 138 and half of Nos. 133, 136 in Ukamnal; half of S. Nos. 163, 164, 168 in Katakanhalli.
Krishnarao died in 1897 leaving widow Rukminibai (D-6).
Siddopant died in 1899 leaving son Gundo, who died in 1901 leaving widow Lakshmibai (D-5).
On 16th December 1901, Lakshmibai adopted Devji, who died on 6th September 1935 leaving three sons (D-1 to D-3: Narayan, Raghavendra, Gundo) and widow Akkubai (D-4).
On 26th April 1944, Rukminibai adopted the plaintiff (appellant).
Plaintiff instituted suit for partition on 29th June 1944 claiming half share in family properties as representing Krishnarao.

Siddopant purchased house under Ex. D-36 (21st May 1871, Rs.200), lands under Ex. D-61 (11th May 1885, S.No.23 Ukamnal, Rs.475), Ex. D-64 (23rd July 1890, S.Nos.2025,2140, Rs.2400; suit concerns S.No.2025). Constructed two houses on S.Nos.639-641 and 634-635 (cost Rs.20,000-25,000). Devji built house on S.Nos.642,644,645 (cost Rs.2,000-4,000). Total investment ~Rs.30,000.
Properties in Schedules A (houses/sites), B (lands). Plaintiff claims ancestral or acquired with joint funds.
Swamirao (other branch) died ~1903 issueless, widow died shortly after; properties (Schedule C) devolved on Devji as nearest agnate.
Plaintiff claims Schedule C properties as preferential heir divesting Devji, or alternatively half share via blending.
Defendants denied adoption validity (not disputed now), claimed only Watan lands ancestral; purchases/houses self-acquisitions; no divestment of Schedule C; no blending.

Trial Court (Civil Judge Senior Division, Bijapur, decree 31st July 1946, Special Civil Suit No.28/1945): Adoption valid; purchases/houses self-acquisitions except half share in S.Nos.639,640 (ancestral); entitled to Schedule C per Anant Bhikappa; no blending.

High Court (Bombay, judgment 12th August 1949, Appeals 63 & 148/1947): Adoption valid; all purchases/houses self-acquisitions (reversed S.Nos.639,640); Schedule C to Devji per Jivaji Annaji; no blending; decree for partition of Watan lands only.
Watan lands ~56 acres, assessment Rs.49; income estimated Rs.150 (trial) or insignificant (High Court); poor quality.
Siddopant Tahsildar in Hyderabad for 40 years, retired on pension; salary plus other income.
Plaintiff tendered judgments in maintenance suits (C.S.445/1903, 177/1941 & appeals) on 17th July 1946, rejected; petition 25th July 1946 dismissed.
House sites: S.Nos.634-635 (sanads D-45,46 recognize prior occupation); 639-641 (no deed for 639, D-47,48 similar); 642,644,645 (D-49-51 similar); 622 purchased by Devji 1909 (D-43); 643 temple.

legal_issues.text: Whether properties purchased by Siddopant and houses constructed by him/Devji are self-acquisitions or joint family properties; burden of proof re nucleus from Watan lands.
Admissibility of maintenance suit judgments under Evidence Act s.13.
Whether house sites without title deeds are ancestral properties.
Whether adopted son (plaintiff) can divest Devji's heirs of Schedule C properties (Swamirao's) via relation back doctrine.
Whether Schedule C properties blended with joint family properties.

petitioner_arguments.text: Nucleus from Watan lands presumes acquisitions with joint funds; burden shifts to defendants to prove self-acquisition without joint aid.
Maintenance judgments admissible under Evidence Act s.13 as assertions of joint family properties.
House sites without title deeds ancestral; presume joint unless proved otherwise.
Adoption relates back; entitled to divest Schedule C as preferential heir per Anant Bhikappa.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Anant Bhikappa Patil v. Shankar Ramchandra Patil (70 IA 232)

petitioner_arguments.text: Schedule C blended with joint properties.

respondent_arguments.text: No sufficient nucleus; income insignificant; acquisitions self-made from Siddopant's service income.
Maintenance judgments irrelevant (quantum only, not title); produced late; reject under Order XIII r.2.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Evidence Act ss.40-44; Order XIII r.2

respondent_arguments.text: No divestment of Schedule C per Jivaji Annaji Full Bench.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Jivaji Annaji v. Hanmant Ramchandra (ILR 1950 Bom 510)

court_reasoning.text: No sufficient nucleus: Watan income too small (not even for maintenance) vs. Rs.30,000 acquisitions; plaintiff failed initial burden.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Income from nucleus key; here insignificant.

court_reasoning.text: Even if burden shifted, defendants discharged: lands intact, income for maintenance only; Siddopant service source.
Documents admissible under s.13 but properly rejected for late production under Order XIII r.2; reopening would prolong trial.
House sites without acquisition deeds (sanads recognize prior occupation) presumed ancestral; plaintiff entitled to half value.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Presume ancestral if long possession, no deed.

court_reasoning.text: Relation back applies only to adoptive father's estate, not collaterals; inheritance vests immediately, not divested; Anant Bhikappa unsound on collaterals.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No hiatus in adoptive father's line only; inconvenient results otherwise.

holdings.text: Maintenance judgments rejected on procedural grounds.
House sites S.Nos.634-635, 639-641, 642/644/645 ancestral; half value to plaintiff; others not.
Adopted son cannot divest collateral inheritance (Schedule C); overrules Anant Bhikappa on this point.

precedents_cited.relevance: Burden of proof on nucleus for joint property claim.

precedents_cited.case_name: Anant Bhikappa Patil Minor v. Shankar Ramchandra Patil
precedents_cited.relevance: Relation back for collateral inheritance unsound.
Relation back for continuity of line.
Validity of adoption not dependent on divestment.
No divestment of collateral inheritance post-death.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Admissibility of judgments as assertions of joint property.

outcome.summary: Appeal partly allowed: affirmed partition of Watan lands and self-acquisition status of purchases/superstructures/Schedule C/no blending; reversed High Court on house sites S.Nos.634-635, 639-641, 642/644/645 as ancestral, granting plaintiff half their value as on suit date; otherwise dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: Partition of Watan lands; half value of specified house sites.

key_quotes.text: "Proof of the existence of a joint family does not lead to the presumption that property held by any member of the family is joint, and the burden rests upon anyone asserting that any item of property was joint to establish the fact."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States law on burden for joint property claims (from Appalaswami).

key_quotes.text: The doctrine of relation back can apply only to the estate of the adoptive father and not to collaterals.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding overruling Anant Bhikappa on collateral succession.

key_quotes.text: "When, therefore, a property is found to have been in the possession of a family from time immemorial, it is not unreasonable to presume that it is ancestral."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for deeming house sites ancestral.
